The rain hammered against the windows of Stockport Police Station with the relentless fury that only a Manchester autumn could deliver. Chief Spencer Hartwell stood at his office window, watching the water cascade down the glass in rivulets that distorted the streetlights below into amber smears. At forty-two, he had seen enough storms to know that this one would pass, but something about tonight felt different. Perhaps it was the way the wind howled through the narrow streets of the old market town, or maybe it was the peculiar restlessness that had been gnawing at him for weeks.

"You're brooding again," came a familiar voice from behind him.

Spencer didn't need to turn around to know that Detective Inspector Marcus Webb had entered his office. After fifteen years of friendship, he could recognize Marcus's footsteps, his breathing pattern, even the particular way he knocked on doors—three quick raps followed by a pause. It was one of those intimate knowledge sets that develop between people who have shared too many late nights, too many crime scenes, and too many pints at the Rose and Crown.

"I don't brood," Spencer replied, finally turning from the window. "I contemplate. There's a difference."

Marcus raised an eyebrow, a gesture that Spencer found annoyingly attractive. At thirty-eight, Marcus retained the lean build of the rugby player he'd once been, though his dark hair now showed threads of silver at the temples. His green eyes held a perpetual glint of mischief that had gotten them both into trouble more times than Spencer cared to count.

"Contemplation requires deep thought," Marcus said, settling into the chair across from Spencer's desk. "You were just staring out the window like a lovesick teenager."

The comment hit closer to home than Spencer would have liked. He had been thinking about Marcus more frequently lately, in ways that went far beyond their professional relationship or even their deep friendship. It was unsettling, this growing awareness of the way Marcus's laugh made his chest tighten, or how his pulse quickened when their hands accidentally touched while reviewing case files.

"What brings you here so late?" Spencer asked, deflecting the conversation away from dangerous territory.

"The Bramhall burglary case," Marcus replied, though his tone suggested there might be other reasons. "I've been going over the witness statements again, and something doesn't add up."

Spencer forced himself to focus on police work, grateful for the distraction. The Bramhall case had been troubling him as well—a series of break-ins in the affluent suburb that showed an unusual pattern. The burglar seemed to know exactly when houses would be empty, suggesting either incredible luck or inside information.

"Show me what you've got," Spencer said, moving around his desk to look over Marcus's shoulder as he spread out the files.

The proximity was a mistake. Spencer caught the familiar scent of Marcus's cologne mixed with something uniquely him—a combination that made Spencer's concentration falter. He tried to focus on the documents, but found himself noticing instead the way Marcus's fingers traced across the pages, the slight stubble on his jaw, the way his shirt stretched across his shoulders.

"Look at this timeline," Marcus was saying, apparently oblivious to Spencer's distraction. "Mrs. Henderson leaves for her book club at seven-thirty every Thursday. The burglar hits her house at eight-fifteen. Mr. Patel always walks his dog at six in the morning on weekends. House gets broken into at six-twenty on a Saturday morning while he's three blocks away."

Spencer forced himself to concentrate on the pattern emerging from the data. "Someone's watching these people. Learning their routines."

"That's what I thought too, but look at this." Marcus pulled out another file. "The Johnsons were supposed to be at their daughter's wedding rehearsal dinner last Friday. But the dinner got moved to Thursday at the last minute—only family knew. Yet our burglar still hit their house on Friday, when it should have been occupied."

"So either our burglar got lucky, or..."

"Or he's getting information from someone who knows these families well enough to know their regular schedules but not well enough to know about last-minute changes."

Spencer nodded, impressed despite himself by Marcus's thorough analysis. This was why they worked so well together—Marcus had an intuitive grasp of human behavior that complemented Spencer's methodical approach to investigation.

"Insurance agent?" Spencer suggested.

"That was my first thought. Crossover Financial handles policies for all the victims. I've got appointments set up to interview the staff tomorrow."

"I'll come with you," Spencer said automatically.

Marcus looked up at him with surprise. "You don't usually get involved in the fieldwork anymore, Chief."

The title stung a little. Marcus only called him "Chief" when he was being formal, maintaining professional distance. Usually it was just "Spence" or "Spencer," delivered with the casual intimacy of their long friendship.

"This case is high-profile," Spencer said, which was true but not the whole truth. The real reason was that he wanted to spend time with Marcus, wanted to watch him work, wanted to be close enough to catch that scent of his cologne and maybe brush against his hand while reaching for evidence bags.

"Suit yourself," Marcus said with a shrug, but Spencer caught something in his expression—a flicker of pleasure, perhaps, or satisfaction.

They spent the next hour going over the case files, their heads bent together over the documents spread across Spencer's desk. The rain continued its assault on the windows, and the police station grew quiet around them as the night shift settled into their routines. Spencer found himself stealing glances at Marcus, memorizing the line of his profile, the way he chewed his lower lip when concentrating.

"We should call it a night," Marcus said eventually, stretching in his chair. "It's nearly midnight."

Spencer didn't want him to leave. The thought surprised him with its intensity. Usually he valued his solitude, used the quiet evening hours to catch up on administrative work or simply to think. But tonight, the prospect of being alone in his office felt unbearably empty.

"Want to grab a drink first?" The words were out before Spencer could stop them. "The Crown should still be open."

Marcus hesitated, and Spencer felt his heart sink. But then Marcus smiled—that easy, warm smile that had been Spencer's undoing from the very beginning of their friendship.

"Why not? It's not like I have anyone waiting for me at home."

The comment was casual, but it reminded Spencer of how little he actually knew about Marcus's personal life. They talked about work constantly, shared jokes and observations about their colleagues, complained about bureaucracy and politics. But deeper subjects—relationships, fears, dreams—remained largely unexplored territory between them.

The Rose and Crown was nearly empty when they arrived, just a few die-hard locals nursing pints in the dim light. Spencer and Marcus claimed their usual table in the corner, a spot that offered privacy and a good view of the room. Old habits from their days as detective constables, when situational awareness could mean the difference between life and death.

"Two pints of bitter," Spencer told the barman, then returned to find Marcus staring thoughtfully into the middle distance.

"Penny for your thoughts," Spencer said, settling into his chair.

"Just thinking about the case. And other things." Marcus accepted his pint with a nod of thanks. "Do you ever wonder what would have happened if we'd made different choices?"

The question was unexpectedly personal, and Spencer felt his pulse quicken. "What kind of different choices?"

"Career choices. Life choices. Relationship choices." Marcus took a long drink, then met Spencer's eyes. "I broke up with Sarah last month."

Spencer tried to hide his reaction, but he felt something leap in his chest. Sarah had been Marcus's on-and-off girlfriend for the past two years—a nice enough woman who worked as a teacher in Manchester. Spencer had always found her pleasant but unremarkable, though he'd never examined too closely why he felt relieved whenever Marcus mentioned their relationship was "on a break."

"I'm sorry," Spencer said, though he wasn't sure he meant it. "What happened?"

"She said I was emotionally unavailable. That I never let her get close enough to matter." Marcus rotated his pint glass between his hands, studying the foam. "She wasn't wrong."

"You're one of the most emotionally available people I know," Spencer protested.

"Am I?" Marcus looked up again, and Spencer saw something vulnerable in his expression. "When's the last time I told you something that really mattered to me? Something that wasn't about work or football or which pub does the best Sunday roast?"

Spencer considered this. Their friendship had always felt deep and comfortable, but Marcus was right—they rarely ventured into truly personal territory. Spencer had attributed this to typical male reticence, the British tendency to keep private matters private. But now he wondered if there were other reasons for their careful boundaries.

"Tell me something now, then," Spencer said, surprising himself with his boldness.

Marcus was quiet for so long that Spencer began to worry he'd overstepped. But then Marcus leaned forward slightly, lowering his voice.

"I've been thinking a lot about what I want from life. And I've realized that most of what makes me happy involves spending time with you."

The words hung in the air between them like a challenge. Spencer felt his mouth go dry, his heart hammering against his ribs. This was the moment when he should make a joke, change the subject, retreat into the safe territory of their established friendship. Instead, he heard himself saying:

"I've been thinking the same thing."The admission seemed to echo in the small space between them, and Spencer watched as something shifted in Marcus's expression—surprise giving way to something deeper, more complicated. The pub's ambient noise—the low murmur of conversation from the other patrons, the clink of glasses, the distant hum of traffic on Wellington Road—seemed to fade into background static.

"Spencer," Marcus began, then stopped, seeming to wrestle with words that wouldn't come easily. His fingers drummed against the scarred wooden table, a nervous habit Spencer had observed countless times during difficult interrogations. "I need to ask you something, and I need you to be honest with me. Has this friendship always felt entirely platonic to you?"

The question landed like a physical blow, not because it was unwelcome, but because it forced Spencer to confront truths he'd been carefully avoiding for months, perhaps years. He thought about all the times he'd found excuses to work late when he knew Marcus would still be at the station. The way he'd felt a stab of irrational jealousy whenever Marcus mentioned dates with Sarah or anyone else. The dreams that had been visiting him with increasing frequency, dreams that left him waking with a mixture of longing and guilt.

"No," Spencer said quietly, the single word carrying the weight of years of unexamined feelings. "It hasn't. And that terrifies me."

Marcus's shoulders seemed to relax slightly, as if he'd been holding his breath. "Why terrifying?"

Spencer took a long drink of his bitter, using the time to organize thoughts that felt scattered and dangerous. "Because I'm your superior officer. Because we've built something good together, professionally and personally, and I don't want to destroy it. Because I'm forty-two years old and I've never felt this way about a man before, and I don't know what that means or what to do with it."

"And because people talk," Marcus added, understanding the unspoken concern. "Small town, smaller police force. Everyone knows everyone else's business."

"That too." Spencer met his eyes across the table. "What about you? How long have you known?"

Marcus smiled ruefully. "Longer than I care to admit. Remember that case three years ago? The domestic violence call that went sideways, when that bastard Thompson came at you with the kitchen knife?"

Spencer nodded. He still had a thin scar on his forearm from that encounter, where Thompson's blade had caught him before Marcus tackled the man to the ground.

"When I saw that knife coming toward you, something inside me just... broke open. The fear I felt wasn't professional concern for a colleague or even worry about a close friend. It was the kind of fear you feel when someone threatens the most important person in your world." Marcus's voice dropped even lower. "That night, I went home and couldn't stop shaking. Not from the adrenaline of the arrest, but from the realization that I was in love with you."

The words hung between them like a bridge that, once crossed, would change everything. Spencer felt the familiar weight of responsibility settling on his shoulders—the need to consider consequences, to think about careers and reputations and the complex dynamics of their professional relationship. But underneath that practical voice was something stronger and more insistent, something that had been growing in silence for far too long.

"I love you too," Spencer said, and the admission felt like stepping off a cliff. "I've been fighting it for months, telling myself it was just admiration for your work, or gratitude for your friendship, or some kind of midlife crisis. But it's not. It's love, and it's real, and I don't know what the hell we're supposed to do about it."

They sat in silence for several minutes, both seeming to absorb the magnitude of what had just passed between them. The barman called last orders, and the remaining patrons began gathering their coats and settling their tabs. Outside, the rain had softened to a steady drizzle, and the streetlights cast wavering reflections on the wet pavement.

"We should go," Marcus said finally, though he made no move to stand. "People will start to notice if we're always the last ones to leave."

Spencer nodded, but found himself reluctant to end this conversation, to return to the world where such admissions would have to be carefully hidden. "Marcus, what happens now? Tomorrow, I mean. Do we pretend this conversation never happened?"

"I don't know if I can do that," Marcus replied honestly. "Now that it's out there between us, I don't know how to go back to the way things were. But I also don't know how we move forward without potentially destroying both our careers."

They walked back to the police station car park in contemplative silence, their footsteps echoing off the wet pavement. Spencer's mind raced through possibilities and complications, trying to map a path through the minefield they'd just entered. The practical challenges were significant—not just the professional implications, but the personal ones as well. Neither of them had experience navigating this kind of relationship, and the stakes felt impossibly high.

"My car's this way," Marcus said when they reached the car park, gesturing toward the far corner where his old Vauxhall sat under a flickering streetlight.

Spencer's BMW was parked in the opposite direction, in the space reserved for senior officers. The symbolism wasn't lost on either of them—even their parking spaces reinforced the hierarchy that complicated everything about their situation.

"The insurance interviews tomorrow," Spencer said, grasping for something concrete and professional to focus on. "What time did you schedule them?"

"Ten o'clock start," Marcus replied, and Spencer could hear him making the same effort to return to safer ground. "I thought we'd begin with the office manager, work our way through the staff. Should take most of the day."

"I'll meet you there," Spencer said, then hesitated. The urge to reach out, to touch Marcus's hand or shoulder, was almost overwhelming. Instead, he shoved his hands deeper into his coat pockets. "And Marcus? Thank you. For being honest. For trusting me with this."

Marcus stepped closer, close enough that Spencer could see the raindrops caught in his dark hair, could smell that familiar scent of cologne and something uniquely him. For a moment, Spencer thought Marcus might actually reach for him, might close the distance between them despite the risk of being seen. Instead, Marcus smiled—a soft, private smile that made Spencer's chest tighten with longing.

"Sleep well, Spencer," Marcus said quietly. "Try not to overthink this into the ground before morning."

"I make no promises," Spencer replied, earning a quiet laugh.

He watched Marcus walk to his car, noting the familiar easy stride, the way he moved with unconscious confidence even in the dim light. When the Vauxhall's taillights disappeared around the corner onto Wellington Road, Spencer remained standing in the car park, letting the light rain soak through his coat while he tried to process everything that had changed in the space of a single evening.

The drive home to his cottage in Bramhall took twenty minutes through empty streets, giving Spencer too much time to think. His house sat at the end of a quiet lane, surrounded by the kind of mature garden that required more attention than his schedule typically allowed. Tonight, as he pulled into his driveway, the familiar sight of his front door felt somehow different, as if the conversation with Marcus had altered not just his internal landscape but his external world as well.

Inside, Spencer poured himself a generous measure of whisky and settled into his favorite armchair by the sitting room fireplace. The house felt larger and quieter than usual, filled with the kind of silence that seemed to amplify every creak of settling timber and whisper of wind through the eaves. He thought about Marcus going home to his own empty flat in Stockport, wondered if he too was sitting awake, trying to make sense of what they'd acknowledged between them.**Chapter 2**

Spencer woke before his alarm, emerging from restless dreams filled with fragments of the previous night's conversation. Pale morning light filtered through his bedroom curtains, casting everything in muted grays that matched his uncertain mood. He'd managed perhaps four hours of actual sleep, the rest of the night spent staring at the ceiling and replaying Marcus's words over and over again. *I was in love with you.* The memory sent the same jolt through his system that it had twelve hours earlier, a mixture of elation and terror that left him feeling off-balance.

The shower did little to clear his head, and breakfast was a perfunctory affair of instant coffee and toast that he barely tasted. Standing in front of his wardrobe, Spencer found himself taking unusual care with his appearance, selecting a navy suit that he knew fitted him well and a tie that Marcus had once complimented. The vanity of it embarrassed him, but he couldn't quite bring himself to change into something more mundane. Today felt significant in ways that went beyond the insurance fraud investigation they'd be conducting.

The drive into Stockport center took him through streets that looked washed clean by the previous night's rain. Autumn leaves clung to wet pavement in patterns of gold and brown, and the air carried that particular crisp quality that marked the transition from September into October. Under normal circumstances, Spencer would have found the morning beautiful, restorative even. Today, however, his mind was too occupied with the prospect of seeing Marcus again, of navigating their first professional interaction in light of everything that had been acknowledged between them.

Crossover Financial occupied the second floor of a converted Victorian building on St. Petersgate, sandwiched between a solicitor's office and a shop selling vintage furniture. Spencer arrived ten minutes early, a habit ingrained by decades of police work, and found Marcus already waiting in the small reception area. Their eyes met across the room, and Spencer felt that familiar flutter of awareness, now complicated by the knowledge that his feelings were reciprocated.

"Morning, Chief," Marcus said, rising from his chair with professional courtesy, but Spencer caught the slight hesitation before the title, the way Marcus's gaze lingered a fraction too long on his face.

"Marcus," Spencer replied, pleased that his voice sounded steady. "Ready for this?"

"Always," Marcus answered, and the familiar confidence in his tone helped ground Spencer in the comfortable rhythms of their professional partnership.

The office manager, a woman named Helen Cartwright in her late fifties, greeted them with the nervous deference that most civilians showed when police arrived at their workplace. Her gray hair was pulled back in a severe bun, and she wore the kind of sensible cardigan that suggested decades of middle management. She led them to a small conference room that smelled of instant coffee and industrial carpet, its walls decorated with motivational posters that had probably been there since the building's conversion.

"I must say, I can't imagine why you'd want to speak with us," Mrs. Cartwright began before they'd even settled into their chairs. "We've always maintained the highest standards of client confidentiality. Any suggestion that someone here might be involved in criminal activity is simply preposterous."

Spencer exchanged a quick glance with Marcus, recognizing the woman's defensive posture as potentially significant. In their experience, people who protested their innocence before being accused often had reasons to feel guilty.

"We're not suggesting anything at this point," Marcus said smoothly, his tone reassuring but professional. "We're simply trying to understand how information about your clients' routines might have become available to unauthorized parties. You handle insurance policies for all the burglary victims, which could be entirely coincidental, but we need to explore all possibilities."

Mrs. Cartwright relaxed slightly at Marcus's diplomatic approach, and Spencer found himself admiring, as he often did, his colleague's intuitive understanding of how to put witnesses at ease. It was a skill that had served them well over the years, and watching Marcus work still gave Spencer a deep sense of professional satisfaction that was now complicated by other, more personal feelings.

"How many staff members have access to client files?" Spencer asked, pulling out his notebook and settling into the familiar routine of systematic questioning.

"Including myself, there are six full-time employees," Mrs. Cartwright replied. "We also have two part-time clerks who help with filing and administrative tasks, but they don't have access to detailed client information. All our files are kept in a locked cabinet system, and only senior staff have keys."

Marcus leaned forward slightly, his green eyes focused intently on Mrs. Cartwright's face. "What about computer records? Are your files digitized?"

"Partially," she admitted. "We've been transitioning to a new system over the past year, but it's been a gradual process. Some of our older files are still paper-only, while newer policies are maintained electronically. Each employee has their own login credentials for the computer system."

Spencer made notes as she spoke, but found himself distracted by Marcus's presence beside him. The familiar scent of his cologne seemed more noticeable today, and Spencer was hyperaware of every small movement—the way Marcus tapped his pen against his notepad when thinking, the slight furrow that appeared between his eyebrows during concentration, the graceful economy of his gestures as he gestured while speaking.

"We'd like to speak with each of your staff members individually," Marcus continued, apparently unaware of Spencer's wandering attention. "And we'll need to review your security protocols for both physical files and computer access. Has anyone left your employment recently? Any disciplinary issues we should know about?"

Mrs. Cartwright's expression became guarded again. "We did have to let someone go about six weeks ago. Martin Fletcher, one of our insurance assessors. But that was purely a performance issue, nothing that would suggest criminal behavior."

Spencer felt his investigative instincts sharpen, pushing his personal preoccupations to the background. "What kind of performance issues?"

"Chronic lateness, missed appointments with clients, incomplete paperwork. Martin had been with us for three years, but his work quality had deteriorated significantly over the past year. We gave him several warnings, tried to work with him, but ultimately had to terminate his employment." Mrs. Cartwright's tone suggested genuine regret. "He was quite upset about it, said we were ruining his life. But honestly, we'd been more than patient."

Marcus and Spencer exchanged another glance, this one heavy with shared professional understanding. A disgruntled former employee with access to client information represented exactly the kind of lead they'd been hoping to find.

"Do you have Martin Fletcher's current contact information?" Marcus asked.

"I'll have to check our personnel files," Mrs. Cartwright replied. "I know he was living in Heaton Mersey when he worked here, but I'm not sure if he's moved since then."

They spent the next hour interviewing the current staff members, a process that yielded little of obvious significance. The employees were a mix of ages and backgrounds, all seeming genuinely shocked by the suggestion that client information might have been compromised. Spencer found himself settling into the comfortable rhythm of investigative work, the methodical process of gathering information and looking for patterns that might reveal the truth beneath surface appearances.

During a brief break between interviews, Spencer and Marcus stepped outside onto St. Petersgate, ostensibly to get some air but really to compare notes away from potentially listening ears. The street bustled with midday activity—office workers grabbing lunch, shoppers moving between the various boutiques and cafes that had sprung up as Stockport worked to reinvent its town center.

"Martin Fletcher sounds promising," Marcus said, lighting a cigarette with the studied casualness of someone who'd been trying to quit for years.

Spencer nodded, though he found himself more focused on the way the autumn sunlight caught the silver threads in Marcus's hair than on the details of their investigation. "Disgruntled former employee with access to victim information and knowledge of their routines. The timeline fits as well—he was terminated six weeks ago, and the burglaries started four weeks ago."

"Gives him time to scout locations, learn schedules, plan his approach," Marcus agreed. "We should track him down this afternoon, see what he's been up to since losing his job."

They stood in comfortable silence for a moment, watching the flow of pedestrian traffic while ostensibly reviewing their notes. Spencer was acutely aware of the foot of space between them, of how easy it would be to close that distance, to brush his fingers against Marcus's hand or shoulder. The urge was so strong that he had to consciously step slightly away, reminding himself that they were in public, in broad daylight, surrounded by people who might know them professionally.

"Spencer," Marcus said quietly, his voice pitched low enough that passersby wouldn't overhear. "About last night. I've been thinking—"

"We should probably discuss that later," Spencer interrupted, glancing around nervously. "When we're not in the middle of town conducting interviews."

Marcus followed his gaze, understanding immediately. "Right. Of course. It's just... I wanted you to know that I haven't changed my mind about anything I said. In case you were wondering."

The simple statement sent warmth spreading through Spencer's chest, a feeling of relief he hadn't realized he'd been needing. Some part of him had worried that Marcus might wake up regretting his honesty, might want to pretend their conversation had never happened.

"Neither have I," Spencer replied softly, then cleared his throat and returned to safer ground. "We should finish up here and then track down Martin Fletcher's current address. I want to interview him before he has a chance to hear that we've been asking questions about him."

The remainder of their time at Crossover Financial was productive but unremarkable. Mrs. Cartwright provided them with Martin Fletcher's last known address and employment references, along with copies of his personnel file and disciplinary records. The picture that emerged was of a man whose life had been gradually falling apart—financial difficulties, relationship problems, and the deteriorating work performance that had ultimately cost him his job.

"Classic profile for someone who might turn to crime," Marcus observed as they walked back to their cars. "Financial pressure, sense of grievance against his former employer, detailed knowledge of potential targets."

Spencer agreed, but found himself only half-focused on the case details. Instead, he was thinking about the careful distance Marcus had maintained throughout the morning, the way they'd both been scrupulously professional in their interactions, the weight of unspoken thoughts that seemed to hover between them during every pause in conversation. It felt unsustainable, this careful pretense that nothing had changed between them, but Spencer wasn't sure what alternative they had.

"I'll drive," Spencer said when they reached the car park. "Martin Fletcher's address is in Heaton Mersey, so we'll take the A6 south."

Marcus nodded and slipped into the passenger seat of Spencer's BMW, settling back with the ease of someone who'd made this journey countless times over the years. The familiarity of it was both comforting and nerve-wracking—Spencer was hyperaware of Marcus's presence in the confined space of the car, of the way his cologne mingled with the scent of leather upholstery, of how his presence seemed to fill the vehicle despite his lean frame.

The drive to Heaton Mersey took them through the suburbs south of Stockport, past rows of terraced houses and small commercial districts that reflected the area's working-class character. Spencer found himself stealing glances at Marcus as they drove, noting the way he gazed thoughtfully out the passenger window, the absent way he drummed his fingers against his thigh when thinking through a problem.

"Turn left here," Marcus said, consulting the street map spread across his lap. "Fletcher's address should be about halfway down Cromwell Road."

The house, when they found it, was a narrow terrace squeezed between identical properties, its front garden overgrown and its paintwork showing signs of neglect. A "To Let" sign in the front window suggested that Martin Fletcher was no longer in residence, but Spencer pulled up to the curb anyway, hoping they might learn something from neighbors or find forwarding information.

Their knock was answered by an elderly woman in her seventies, her gray hair covered by a floral headscarf and her sharp eyes taking in their formal clothing and official bearing with obvious suspicion.

"Mrs. Morrison?" Spencer asked, consulting his notes. "I'm Chief Inspector Hartwell from Stockport Police, and this is Detective Inspector Webb. We're trying to locate Martin Fletcher, who used to live next door at number forty-seven."

"Martin?" Mrs. Morrison's expression shifted from suspicion to something approaching pity. "Oh, that poor boy. Lost his job, then lost his flat when he couldn't pay the rent. Haven't seen him for weeks now."

Marcus stepped forward slightly, his tone gentle and encouraging. "Do you know where he went? Any family or friends he might be staying with?"

"He mentioned having a cousin somewhere in Manchester, but I never got the details. Martin kept to himself mostly, especially after his girlfriend left him. That was back in the spring, I think. He took it quite hard." Mrs. Morrison shook her head sadly. "Such a shame. He seemed like a nice enough lad when he first moved in, always polite, helped me with my shopping bags when he saw me struggling. But these past months, he looked terrible. Thin as a rake, dark circles under his eyes. I wondered if he was taking drugs or something."

Spencer and Marcus exchanged glances, both recognizing the signs of someone whose life was spiraling out of control. Financial problems, job loss, relationship breakdown, possible substance abuse—it was a trajectory they'd seen many times before, one that often ended in desperate measures.

"Did you ever see him with expensive items that seemed out of place?" Spencer asked. "New electronics, jewelry, anything that might have suggested he had money coming from somewhere?"

Mrs. Morrison considered this carefully. "Now that you mention it, I did see him loading some boxes into a car a few weeks back. Looked like computer equipment or something electronic. I thought maybe he was selling his own things to make ends meet, but the boxes looked brand new, still in packaging."

This was promising. Spencer felt the familiar excitement of an investigation beginning to coalesce around a viable suspect. "Can you describe the car?"

"Dark blue, I think. Not very new, but well-maintained. A hatchback of some kind, though I couldn't tell you the make or model. Cars all look the same to me these days." Mrs. Morrison wrapped her cardigan more tightly around her shoulders as a cool breeze picked up. "Is Martin in some kind of trouble?"

"We just need to speak with him," Marcus replied diplomatically. "If you see him or hear from him, would you give us a call?" He handed her one of his business cards. "Any information would be helpful."

They thanked Mrs. Morrison and returned to the car, both feeling energized by the confirmation that their theory about Martin Fletcher seemed to be on the right track. The mention of new electronics being loaded into a car was particularly significant, potentially providing a direct link between Fletcher and the stolen goods from the recent burglaries.

"We need to find out where Fletcher's staying now," Spencer said as they drove back toward Stockport. "Check with his former references, see if we can track down this cousin in Manchester. And we should alert uniform patrol to keep an eye out for a dark blue hatchback in the Bramhall area."

Marcus nodded, already making notes on his pad. "I'll also run his name through the system, see if he's had any recent contact with police. Might give us leads on current associates or addresses."

The afternoon was wearing on, and Spencer realized they'd been working together for hours without any of the awkwardness he'd feared might follow their previous night's conversation. The familiar rhythms of investigation seemed to provide a comfortable structure that allowed them to function normally despite the personal undercurrents that had emerged between them. It was both reassuring and slightly frustrating—part of him wanted to acknowledge what had changed, to find some way of integrating their personal revelation with their professional partnership.**Chapter 3**

Back at the police station, Spencer and Marcus settled into the systematic work of tracking down Martin Fletcher's current whereabouts. The incident room they commandeered was one of the smaller spaces, cramped but functional, with whiteboards covering one wall and a collection of mismatched chairs gathered around a table scarred by years of coffee cups and case files. Spencer found himself acutely aware of the intimate scale of the room, the way it seemed to amplify Marcus's presence and make the careful professional distance they'd been maintaining feel increasingly artificial.

Marcus had shed his jacket and rolled up his sleeves, revealing forearms that Spencer tried not to stare at as his colleague worked through a stack of phone directories and computer printouts. There was something almost domestic about the scene—the two of them working companionably in the small space, Marcus occasionally reading relevant information aloud, Spencer making notes on the whiteboard and connecting potential leads with red marker lines. It felt like a glimpse of what their life might be like if circumstances were different, if they were free to acknowledge the intimacy that had always underpinned their professional partnership.

"Found something," Marcus announced, looking up from his computer screen with satisfaction. "Martin Fletcher's National Insurance records show he signed on for unemployment benefits three weeks ago. The address listed is a bedsit in Levenshulme—forty-seven Burnage Lane, flat B. That's got to be more current than the Heaton Mersey address."

Spencer added the new address to their growing collection of information on the whiteboard, noting how the timeline aligned perfectly with their theory. Fletcher loses his job six weeks ago, gets evicted from his flat, moves to cheaper accommodation in Manchester, and starts collecting benefits while potentially supplementing his income through burglary. It was a depressingly familiar pattern of decline that Spencer had seen countless times throughout his career.

"Levenshulme's a bit of a trek from the Bramhall area," Spencer observed, studying the map they'd pinned to the wall. "But manageable if you're motivated and have transport. Mrs. Morrison mentioned seeing him with a car, so that fits."

Marcus leaned back in his chair, stretching in a way that made Spencer momentarily lose his train of thought. "We should pay him a visit this evening. If he's our burglar, he'll be working nights, so we might catch him at home during the afternoon or early evening."

The prospect of spending more time together, of continuing their investigation into the evening hours, sent a flutter of anticipation through Spencer's chest that had nothing to do with the case they were pursuing. As afternoon faded toward evening, Spencer and Marcus found themselves coordinating a rapidly expanding investigation from the Crossover Financial offices, using Jennifer Walsh and her colleagues as sources of information while simultaneously working to ensure their safety and gather evidence that might lead to Sterling's capture. The familiar rhythms of their professional partnership felt both reassuring and charged with new significance, their personal relationship adding layers of concern and motivation to work that had always been important but now felt personally urgent as well. They were hunting a killer together, and the success of their investigation would determine not only justice for Helen Cartwright but the safety of other potential victims who remained in Sterling's crosshairs.

The building around them gradually emptied as normal business hours ended and other tenants departed for their weekend activities, leaving Spencer and Marcus working in the growing quiet of an office building after hours. The solitude was both convenient for their investigation and slightly unnerving, given that Sterling had demonstrated familiarity with the building and willingness to use violence against people connected to Crossover Financial. Spencer found himself hyperaware of sounds from the hallway and street below, conscious that they might themselves have become targets if Sterling decided that eliminating the investigating officers was necessary for his survival.

"We should probably relocate to the police station," Marcus suggested, echoing Spencer's own growing concern about their vulnerability in an isolated office building that Sterling knew intimately. "We've gathered what information we can here, and continuing the investigation from a secure location makes more sense than staying in a place where we might be putting ourselves and remaining staff at risk. Besides, we need access to proper computer terminals and communication equipment to coordinate the manhunt effectively."

Spencer agreed, understanding that their investigation had reached the point where they needed the full resources of major crimes investigation rather than the informal information gathering they had been conducting at Crossover Financial. The evidence they had collected painted a disturbing picture of sophisticated criminal activity involving technical expertise, systematic violence, and careful planning that would require equally sophisticated investigative methods to counter effectively. As they prepared to leave the insurance company offices and return to the police station, Spencer felt the weight of responsibility for both solving Helen Cartwright's murder and preventing Sterling from claiming additional victims settling heavily on his shoulders.

The rain hammered against the windows of Stockport Police Station with the relentless fury that only a Manchester autumn could deliver. Chief Spencer Hartwell stood at his office window, watching the water cascade down the glass in rivulets that distorted the streetlights below into amber smears. At forty-two, he had seen enough storms to know that this one would pass, but something about tonight felt different. Perhaps it was the way the wind howled through the narrow streets of the old market town, or maybe it was the peculiar restlessness that had been gnawing at him for weeks.

"You're brooding again," came a familiar voice from behind him.

Spencer didn't need to turn around to know that Detective Inspector Marcus Webb had entered his office. After fifteen years of friendship, he could recognize Marcus's footsteps, his breathing pattern, even the particular way he knocked on doors—three quick raps followed by a pause. It was one of those intimate knowledge sets that develop between people who have shared too many late nights, too many crime scenes, and too many pints at the Rose and Crown.

"I don't brood," Spencer replied, finally turning from the window. "I contemplate. There's a difference."

Marcus raised an eyebrow, a gesture that Spencer found annoyingly attractive. At thirty-eight, Marcus retained the lean build of the rugby player he'd once been, though his dark hair now showed threads of silver at the temples. His green eyes held a perpetual glint of mischief that had gotten them both into trouble more times than Spencer cared to count.

"Contemplation requires deep thought," Marcus said, settling into the chair across from Spencer's desk. "You were just staring out the window like a lovesick teenager."

The comment hit closer to home than Spencer would have liked. He had been thinking about Marcus more frequently lately, in ways that went far beyond their professional relationship or even their deep friendship. It was unsettling, this growing awareness of the way Marcus's laugh made his chest tighten, or how his pulse quickened when their hands accidentally touched while reviewing case files.

"What brings you here so late?" Spencer asked, deflecting the conversation away from dangerous territory.

"The Bramhall burglary case," Marcus replied, though his tone suggested there might be other reasons. "I've been going over the witness statements again, and something doesn't add up."

Spencer forced himself to focus on police work, grateful for the distraction. The Bramhall case had been troubling him as well—a series of break-ins in the affluent suburb that showed an unusual pattern. The burglar seemed to know exactly when houses would be empty, suggesting either incredible luck or inside information.

"Show me what you've got," Spencer said, moving around his desk to look over Marcus's shoulder as he spread out the files.

The proximity was a mistake. Spencer caught the familiar scent of Marcus's cologne mixed with something uniquely him—a combination that made Spencer's concentration falter. He tried to focus on the documents, but found himself noticing instead the way Marcus's fingers traced across the pages, the slight stubble on his jaw, the way his shirt stretched across his shoulders.

"Look at this timeline," Marcus was saying, apparently oblivious to Spencer's distraction. "Mrs. Henderson leaves for her book club at seven-thirty every Thursday. The burglar hits her house at eight-fifteen. Mr. Patel always walks his dog at six in the morning on weekends. House gets broken into at six-twenty on a Saturday morning while he's three blocks away."

Spencer forced himself to concentrate on the pattern emerging from the data. "Someone's watching these people. Learning their routines."

"That's what I thought too, but look at this." Marcus pulled out another file. "The Johnsons were supposed to be at their daughter's wedding rehearsal dinner last Friday. But the dinner got moved to Thursday at the last minute—only family knew. Yet our burglar still hit their house on Friday, when it should have been occupied."

"So either our burglar got lucky, or..."

"Or he's getting information from someone who knows these families well enough to know their regular schedules but not well enough to know about last-minute changes."

Spencer nodded, impressed despite himself by Marcus's thorough analysis. This was why they worked so well together—Marcus had an intuitive grasp of human behavior that complemented Spencer's methodical approach to investigation.

"Insurance agent?" Spencer suggested.

"That was my first thought. Crossover Financial handles policies for all the victims. I've got appointments set up to interview the staff tomorrow."

"I'll come with you," Spencer said automatically.

Marcus looked up at him with surprise. "You don't usually get involved in the fieldwork anymore, Chief."

The title stung a little. Marcus only called him "Chief" when he was being formal, maintaining professional distance. Usually it was just "Spence" or "Spencer," delivered with the casual intimacy of their long friendship.

"This case is high-profile," Spencer said, which was true but not the whole truth. The real reason was that he wanted to spend time with Marcus, wanted to watch him work, wanted to be close enough to catch that scent of his cologne and maybe brush against his hand while reaching for evidence bags.

"Suit yourself," Marcus said with a shrug, but Spencer caught something in his expression—a flicker of pleasure, perhaps, or satisfaction.

They spent the next hour going over the case files, their heads bent together over the documents spread across Spencer's desk. The rain continued its assault on the windows, and the police station grew quiet around them as the night shift settled into their routines. Spencer found himself stealing glances at Marcus, memorizing the line of his profile, the way he chewed his lower lip when concentrating.

"We should call it a night," Marcus said eventually, stretching in his chair. "It's nearly midnight."

Spencer didn't want him to leave. The thought surprised him with its intensity. Usually he valued his solitude, used the quiet evening hours to catch up on administrative work or simply to think. But tonight, the prospect of being alone in his office felt unbearably empty.

"Want to grab a drink first?" The words were out before Spencer could stop them. "The Crown should still be open."

Marcus hesitated, and Spencer felt his heart sink. But then Marcus smiled—that easy, warm smile that had been Spencer's undoing from the very beginning of their friendship.

"Why not? It's not like I have anyone waiting for me at home."

The comment was casual, but it reminded Spencer of how little he actually knew about Marcus's personal life. They talked about work constantly, shared jokes and observations about their colleagues, complained about bureaucracy and politics. But deeper subjects—relationships, fears, dreams—remained largely unexplored territory between them.

The Rose and Crown was nearly empty when they arrived, just a few die-hard locals nursing pints in the dim light. Spencer and Marcus claimed their usual table in the corner, a spot that offered privacy and a good view of the room. Old habits from their days as detective constables, when situational awareness could mean the difference between life and death.

"Two pints of bitter," Spencer told the barman, then returned to find Marcus staring thoughtfully into the middle distance.

"Penny for your thoughts," Spencer said, settling into his chair.

"Just thinking about the case. And other things." Marcus accepted his pint with a nod of thanks. "Do you ever wonder what would have happened if we'd made different choices?"

The question was unexpectedly personal, and Spencer felt his pulse quicken. "What kind of different choices?"

"Career choices. Life choices. Relationship choices." Marcus took a long drink, then met Spencer's eyes. "I broke up with Sarah last month."

Spencer tried to hide his reaction, but he felt something leap in his chest. Sarah had been Marcus's on-and-off girlfriend for the past two years—a nice enough woman who worked as a teacher in Manchester. Spencer had always found her pleasant but unremarkable, though he'd never examined too closely why he felt relieved whenever Marcus mentioned their relationship was "on a break."

"I'm sorry," Spencer said, though he wasn't sure he meant it. "What happened?"

"She said I was emotionally unavailable. That I never let her get close enough to matter." Marcus rotated his pint glass between his hands, studying the foam. "She wasn't wrong."

"You're one of the most emotionally available people I know," Spencer protested.

"Am I?" Marcus looked up again, and Spencer saw something vulnerable in his expression. "When's the last time I told you something that really mattered to me? Something that wasn't about work or football or which pub does the best Sunday roast?"

Spencer considered this. Their friendship had always felt deep and comfortable, but Marcus was right—they rarely ventured into truly personal territory. Spencer had attributed this to typical male reticence, the British tendency to keep private matters private. But now he wondered if there were other reasons for their careful boundaries.

"Tell me something now, then," Spencer said, surprising himself with his boldness.

Marcus was quiet for so long that Spencer began to worry he'd overstepped. But then Marcus leaned forward slightly, lowering his voice.

"I've been thinking a lot about what I want from life. And I've realized that most of what makes me happy involves spending time with you."

The words hung in the air between them like a challenge. Spencer felt his mouth go dry, his heart hammering against his ribs. This was the moment when he should make a joke, change the subject, retreat into the safe territory of their established friendship. Instead, he heard himself saying:

"I've been thinking the same thing."

The admission seemed to echo in the small space between them, and Spencer watched as something shifted in Marcus's expression—surprise giving way to something deeper, more complicated. The pub's ambient noise—the low murmur of conversation from the other patrons, the clink of glasses, the distant hum of traffic on Wellington Road—seemed to fade into background static.

"Spencer," Marcus began, then stopped, seeming to wrestle with words that wouldn't come easily. His fingers drummed against the scarred wooden table, a nervous habit Spencer had observed countless times during difficult interrogations. "I need to ask you something, and I need you to be honest with me. Has this friendship always felt entirely platonic to you?"

The question landed like a physical blow, not because it was unwelcome, but because it forced Spencer to confront truths he'd been carefully avoiding for months, perhaps years. He thought about all the times he'd found excuses to work late when he knew Marcus would still be at the station. The way he'd felt a stab of irrational jealousy whenever Marcus mentioned dates with Sarah or anyone else. The dreams that had been visiting him with increasing frequency, dreams that left him waking with a mixture of longing and guilt.

"No," Spencer said quietly, the single word carrying the weight of years of unexamined feelings. "It hasn't. And that terrifies me."

Marcus's shoulders seemed to relax slightly, as if he'd been holding his breath. "Why terrifying?"

Spencer took a long drink of his bitter, using the time to organize thoughts that felt scattered and dangerous. "Because I'm your superior officer. Because we've built something good together, professionally and personally, and I don't want to destroy it. Because I'm forty-two years old and I've never felt this way about a man before, and I don't know what that means or what to do with it."

"And because people talk," Marcus added, understanding the unspoken concern. "Small town, smaller police force. Everyone knows everyone else's business."

"That too." Spencer met his eyes across the table. "What about you? How long have you known?"

Marcus smiled ruefully. "Longer than I care to admit. Remember that case three years ago? The domestic violence call that went sideways, when that bastard Thompson came at you with the kitchen knife?"

Spencer nodded. He still had a thin scar on his forearm from that encounter, where Thompson's blade had caught him before Marcus tackled the man to the ground.

"When I saw that knife coming toward you, something inside me just... broke open. The fear I felt wasn't professional concern for a colleague or even worry about a close friend. It was the kind of fear you feel when someone threatens the most important person in your world." Marcus's voice dropped even lower. "That night, I went home and couldn't stop shaking. Not from the adrenaline of the arrest, but from the realization that I was in love with you."

The words hung between them like a bridge that, once crossed, would change everything. Spencer felt the familiar weight of responsibility settling on his shoulders—the need to consider consequences, to think about careers and reputations and the complex dynamics of their professional relationship. But underneath that practical voice was something stronger and more insistent, something that had been growing in silence for far too long.

"I love you too," Spencer said, and the admission felt like stepping off a cliff. "I've been fighting it for months, telling myself it was just admiration for your work, or gratitude for your friendship, or some kind of midlife crisis. But it's not. It's love, and it's real, and I don't know what the hell we're supposed to do about it."

They sat in silence for several minutes, both seeming to absorb the magnitude of what had just passed between them. The barman called last orders, and the remaining patrons began gathering their coats and settling their tabs. Outside, the rain had softened to a steady drizzle, and the streetlights cast wavering reflections on the wet pavement.

"We should go," Marcus said finally, though he made no move to stand. "People will start to notice if we're always the last ones to leave."

Spencer nodded, but found himself reluctant to end this conversation, to return to the world where such admissions would have to be carefully hidden. "Marcus, what happens now? Tomorrow, I mean. Do we pretend this conversation never happened?"

"I don't know if I can do that," Marcus replied honestly. "Now that it's out there between us, I don't know how to go back to the way things were. But I also don't know how we move forward without potentially destroying both our careers."

They walked back to the police station car park in contemplative silence, their footsteps echoing off the wet pavement. Spencer's mind raced through possibilities and complications, trying to map a path through the minefield they'd just entered. The practical challenges were significant—not just the professional implications, but the personal ones as well. Neither of them had experience navigating this kind of relationship, and the stakes felt impossibly high.

"My car's this way," Marcus said when they reached the car park, gesturing toward the far corner where his old Vauxhall sat under a flickering streetlight.

Spencer's BMW was parked in the opposite direction, in the space reserved for senior officers. The symbolism wasn't lost on either of them—even their parking spaces reinforced the hierarchy that complicated everything about their situation.

"The insurance interviews tomorrow," Spencer said, grasping for something concrete and professional to focus on. "What time did you schedule them?"

"Ten o'clock start," Marcus replied, and Spencer could hear him making the same effort to return to safer ground. "I thought we'd begin with the office manager, work our way through the staff. Should take most of the day."

"I'll meet you there," Spencer said, then hesitated. The urge to reach out, to touch Marcus's hand or shoulder, was almost overwhelming. Instead, he shoved his hands deeper into his coat pockets. "And Marcus? Thank you. For being honest. For trusting me with this."

Marcus stepped closer, close enough that Spencer could see the raindrops caught in his dark hair, could smell that familiar scent of cologne and something uniquely him. For a moment, Spencer thought Marcus might actually reach for him, might close the distance between them despite the risk of being seen. Instead, Marcus smiled—a soft, private smile that made Spencer's chest tighten with longing.

"Sleep well, Spencer," Marcus said quietly. "Try not to overthink this into the ground before morning."

"I make no promises," Spencer replied, earning a quiet laugh.

He watched Marcus walk to his car, noting the familiar easy stride, the way he moved with unconscious confidence even in the dim light. When the Vauxhall's taillights disappeared around the corner onto Wellington Road, Spencer remained standing in the car park, letting the light rain soak through his coat while he tried to process everything that had changed in the space of a single evening.

The drive home to his cottage in Bramhall took twenty minutes through empty streets, giving Spencer too much time to think. His house sat at the end of a quiet lane, surrounded by the kind of mature garden that required more attention than his schedule typically allowed. Tonight, as he pulled into his driveway, the familiar sight of his front door felt somehow different, as if the conversation with Marcus had altered not just his internal landscape but his external world as well.

Inside, Spencer poured himself a generous measure of whisky and settled into his favorite armchair by the sitting room fireplace. The house felt larger and quieter than usual, filled with the kind of silence that seemed to amplify every creak of settling timber and whisper of wind through the eaves. He thought about Marcus going home to his own empty flat in Stockport, wondered if he too was sitting awake, trying to make sense of what they'd acknowledged between them.

**Chapter 2**

Spencer woke before his alarm, emerging from restless dreams filled with fragments of the previous night's conversation. Pale morning light filtered through his bedroom curtains, casting everything in muted grays that matched his uncertain mood. He'd managed perhaps four hours of actual sleep, the rest of the night spent staring at the ceiling and replaying Marcus's words over and over again. *I was in love with you.* The memory sent the same jolt through his system that it had twelve hours earlier, a mixture of elation and terror that left him feeling off-balance.

The shower did little to clear his head, and breakfast was a perfunctory affair of instant coffee and toast that he barely tasted. Standing in front of his wardrobe, Spencer found himself taking unusual care with his appearance, selecting a navy suit that he knew fitted him well and a tie that Marcus had once complimented. The vanity of it embarrassed him, but he couldn't quite bring himself to change into something more mundane. Today felt significant in ways that went beyond the insurance fraud investigation they'd be conducting.

The drive into Stockport center took him through streets that looked washed clean by the previous night's rain. Autumn leaves clung to wet pavement in patterns of gold and brown, and the air carried that particular crisp quality that marked the transition from September into October. Under normal circumstances, Spencer would have found the morning beautiful, restorative even. Today, however, his mind was too occupied with the prospect of seeing Marcus again, of navigating their first professional interaction in light of everything that had been acknowledged between them.

Crossover Financial occupied the second floor of a converted Victorian building on St. Petersgate, sandwiched between a solicitor's office and a shop selling vintage furniture. Spencer arrived ten minutes early, a habit ingrained by decades of police work, and found Marcus already waiting in the small reception area. Their eyes met across the room, and Spencer felt that familiar flutter of awareness, now complicated by the knowledge that his feelings were reciprocated.

"Morning, Chief," Marcus said, rising from his chair with professional courtesy, but Spencer caught the slight hesitation before the title, the way Marcus's gaze lingered a fraction too long on his face.

"Marcus," Spencer replied, pleased that his voice sounded steady. "Ready for this?"

"Always," Marcus answered, and the familiar confidence in his tone helped ground Spencer in the comfortable rhythms of their professional partnership.

The office manager, a woman named Helen Cartwright in her late fifties, greeted them with the nervous deference that most civilians showed when police arrived at their workplace. Her gray hair was pulled back in a severe bun, and she wore the kind of sensible cardigan that suggested decades of middle management. She led them to a small conference room that smelled of instant coffee and industrial carpet, its walls decorated with motivational posters that had probably been there since the building's conversion.

"I must say, I can't imagine why you'd want to speak with us," Mrs. Cartwright began before they'd even settled into their chairs. "We've always maintained the highest standards of client confidentiality. Any suggestion that someone here might be involved in criminal activity is simply preposterous."

Spencer exchanged a quick glance with Marcus, recognizing the woman's defensive posture as potentially significant. In their experience, people who protested their innocence before being accused often had reasons to feel guilty.

"We're not suggesting anything at this point," Marcus said smoothly, his tone reassuring but professional. "We're simply trying to understand how information about your clients' routines might have become available to unauthorized parties. You handle insurance policies for all the burglary victims, which could be entirely coincidental, but we need to explore all possibilities."

Mrs. Cartwright relaxed slightly at Marcus's diplomatic approach, and Spencer found himself admiring, as he often did, his colleague's intuitive understanding of how to put witnesses at ease. It was a skill that had served them well over the years, and watching Marcus work still gave Spencer a deep sense of professional satisfaction that was now complicated by other, more personal feelings.

"How many staff members have access to client files?" Spencer asked, pulling out his notebook and settling into the familiar routine of systematic questioning.

"Including myself, there are six full-time employees," Mrs. Cartwright replied. "We also have two part-time clerks who help with filing and administrative tasks, but they don't have access to detailed client information. All our files are kept in a locked cabinet system, and only senior staff have keys."

Marcus leaned forward slightly, his green eyes focused intently on Mrs. Cartwright's face. "What about computer records? Are your files digitized?"

"Partially," she admitted. "We've been transitioning to a new system over the past year, but it's been a gradual process. Some of our older files are still paper-only, while newer policies are maintained electronically. Each employee has their own login credentials for the computer system."

Spencer made notes as she spoke, but found himself distracted by Marcus's presence beside him. The familiar scent of his cologne seemed more noticeable today, and Spencer was hyperaware of every small movement—the way Marcus tapped his pen against his notepad when thinking, the slight furrow that appeared between his eyebrows during concentration, the graceful economy of his gestures as he gestured while speaking.

"We'd like to speak with each of your staff members individually," Marcus continued, apparently unaware of Spencer's wandering attention. "And we'll need to review your security protocols for both physical files and computer access. Has anyone left your employment recently? Any disciplinary issues we should know about?"

Mrs. Cartwright's expression became guarded again. "We did have to let someone go about six weeks ago. Martin Fletcher, one of our insurance assessors. But that was purely a performance issue, nothing that would suggest criminal behavior."

Spencer felt his investigative instincts sharpen, pushing his personal preoccupations to the background. "What kind of performance issues?"

"Chronic lateness, missed appointments with clients, incomplete paperwork. Martin had been with us for three years, but his work quality had deteriorated significantly over the past year. We gave him several warnings, tried to work with him, but ultimately had to terminate his employment." Mrs. Cartwright's tone suggested genuine regret. "He was quite upset about it, said we were ruining his life. But honestly, we'd been more than patient."

Marcus and Spencer exchanged another glance, this one heavy with shared professional understanding. A disgruntled former employee with access to client information represented exactly the kind of lead they'd been hoping to find.

"Do you have Martin Fletcher's current contact information?" Marcus asked.

"I'll have to check our personnel files," Mrs. Cartwright replied. "I know he was living in Heaton Mersey when he worked here, but I'm not sure if he's moved since then."

They spent the next hour interviewing the current staff members, a process that yielded little of obvious significance. The employees were a mix of ages and backgrounds, all seeming genuinely shocked by the suggestion that client information might have been compromised. Spencer found himself settling into the comfortable rhythm of investigative work, the methodical process of gathering information and looking for patterns that might reveal the truth beneath surface appearances.

During a brief break between interviews, Spencer and Marcus stepped outside onto St. Petersgate, ostensibly to get some air but really to compare notes away from potentially listening ears. The street bustled with midday activity—office workers grabbing lunch, shoppers moving between the various boutiques and cafes that had sprung up as Stockport worked to reinvent its town center.

"Martin Fletcher sounds promising," Marcus said, lighting a cigarette with the studied casualness of someone who'd been trying to quit for years.

Spencer nodded, though he found himself more focused on the way the autumn sunlight caught the silver threads in Marcus's hair than on the details of their investigation. "Disgruntled former employee with access to victim information and knowledge of their routines. The timeline fits as well—he was terminated six weeks ago, and the burglaries started four weeks ago."

"Gives him time to scout locations, learn schedules, plan his approach," Marcus agreed. "We should track him down this afternoon, see what he's been up to since losing his job."

They stood in comfortable silence for a moment, watching the flow of pedestrian traffic while ostensibly reviewing their notes. Spencer was acutely aware of the foot of space between them, of how easy it would be to close that distance, to brush his fingers against Marcus's hand or shoulder. The urge was so strong that he had to consciously step slightly away, reminding himself that they were in public, in broad daylight, surrounded by people who might know them professionally.

"Spencer," Marcus said quietly, his voice pitched low enough that passersby wouldn't overhear. "About last night. I've been thinking—"

"We should probably discuss that later," Spencer interrupted, glancing around nervously. "When we're not in the middle of town conducting interviews."

Marcus followed his gaze, understanding immediately. "Right. Of course. It's just... I wanted you to know that I haven't changed my mind about anything I said. In case you were wondering."

The simple statement sent warmth spreading through Spencer's chest, a feeling of relief he hadn't realized he'd been needing. Some part of him had worried that Marcus might wake up regretting his honesty, might want to pretend their conversation had never happened.

"Neither have I," Spencer replied softly, then cleared his throat and returned to safer ground. "We should finish up here and then track down Martin Fletcher's current address. I want to interview him before he has a chance to hear that we've been asking questions about him."

The remainder of their time at Crossover Financial was productive but unremarkable. Mrs. Cartwright provided them with Martin Fletcher's last known address and employment references, along with copies of his personnel file and disciplinary records. The picture that emerged was of a man whose life had been gradually falling apart—financial difficulties, relationship problems, and the deteriorating work performance that had ultimately cost him his job.

"Classic profile for someone who might turn to crime," Marcus observed as they walked back to their cars. "Financial pressure, sense of grievance against his former employer, detailed knowledge of potential targets."

Spencer agreed, but found himself only half-focused on the case details. Instead, he was thinking about the careful distance Marcus had maintained throughout the morning, the way they'd both been scrupulously professional in their interactions, the weight of unspoken thoughts that seemed to hover between them during every pause in conversation. It felt unsustainable, this careful pretense that nothing had changed between them, but Spencer wasn't sure what alternative they had.

"I'll drive," Spencer said when they reached the car park. "Martin Fletcher's address is in Heaton Mersey, so we'll take the A6 south."

Marcus nodded and slipped into the passenger seat of Spencer's BMW, settling back with the ease of someone who'd made this journey countless times over the years. The familiarity of it was both comforting and nerve-wracking—Spencer was hyperaware of Marcus's presence in the confined space of the car, of the way his cologne mingled with the scent of leather upholstery, of how his presence seemed to fill the vehicle despite his lean frame.

The drive to Heaton Mersey took them through the suburbs south of Stockport, past rows of terraced houses and small commercial districts that reflected the area's working-class character. Spencer found himself stealing glances at Marcus as they drove, noting the way he gazed thoughtfully out the passenger window, the absent way he drummed his fingers against his thigh when thinking through a problem.

"Turn left here," Marcus said, consulting the street map spread across his lap. "Fletcher's address should be about halfway down Cromwell Road."

The house, when they found it, was a narrow terrace squeezed between identical properties, its front garden overgrown and its paintwork showing signs of neglect. A "To Let" sign in the front window suggested that Martin Fletcher was no longer in residence, but Spencer pulled up to the curb anyway, hoping they might learn something from neighbors or find forwarding information.

Their knock was answered by an elderly woman in her seventies, her gray hair covered by a floral headscarf and her sharp eyes taking in their formal clothing and official bearing with obvious suspicion.

"Mrs. Morrison?" Spencer asked, consulting his notes. "I'm Chief Inspector Hartwell from Stockport Police, and this is Detective Inspector Webb. We're trying to locate Martin Fletcher, who used to live next door at number forty-seven."

"Martin?" Mrs. Morrison's expression shifted from suspicion to something approaching pity. "Oh, that poor boy. Lost his job, then lost his flat when he couldn't pay the rent. Haven't seen him for weeks now."

Marcus stepped forward slightly, his tone gentle and encouraging. "Do you know where he went? Any family or friends he might be staying with?"

"He mentioned having a cousin somewhere in Manchester, but I never got the details. Martin kept to himself mostly, especially after his girlfriend left him. That was back in the spring, I think. He took it quite hard." Mrs. Morrison shook her head sadly. "Such a shame. He seemed like a nice enough lad when he first moved in, always polite, helped me with my shopping bags when he saw me struggling. But these past months, he looked terrible. Thin as a rake, dark circles under his eyes. I wondered if he was taking drugs or something."

Spencer and Marcus exchanged glances, both recognizing the signs of someone whose life was spiraling out of control. Financial problems, job loss, relationship breakdown, possible substance abuse—it was a trajectory they'd seen many times before, one that often ended in desperate measures.

"Did you ever see him with expensive items that seemed out of place?" Spencer asked. "New electronics, jewelry, anything that might have suggested he had money coming from somewhere?"

Mrs. Morrison considered this carefully. "Now that you mention it, I did see him loading some boxes into a car a few weeks back. Looked like computer equipment or something electronic. I thought maybe he was selling his own things to make ends meet, but the boxes looked brand new, still in packaging."

This was promising. Spencer felt the familiar excitement of an investigation beginning to coalesce around a viable suspect. "Can you describe the car?"

"Dark blue, I think. Not very new, but well-maintained. A hatchback of some kind, though I couldn't tell you the make or model. Cars all look the same to me these days." Mrs. Morrison wrapped her cardigan more tightly around her shoulders as a cool breeze picked up. "Is Martin in some kind of trouble?"

"We just need to speak with him," Marcus replied diplomatically. "If you see him or hear from him, would you give us a call?" He handed her one of his business cards. "Any information would be helpful."

They thanked Mrs. Morrison and returned to the car, both feeling energized by the confirmation that their theory about Martin Fletcher seemed to be on the right track. The mention of new electronics being loaded into a car was particularly significant, potentially providing a direct link between Fletcher and the stolen goods from the recent burglaries.

"We need to find out where Fletcher's staying now," Spencer said as they drove back toward Stockport. "Check with his former references, see if we can track down this cousin in Manchester. And we should alert uniform patrol to keep an eye out for a dark blue hatchback in the Bramhall area."

Marcus nodded, already making notes on his pad. "I'll also run his name through the system, see if he's had any recent contact with police. Might give us leads on current associates or addresses."

The afternoon was wearing on, and Spencer realized they'd been working together for hours without any of the awkwardness he'd feared might follow their previous night's conversation. The familiar rhythms of investigation seemed to provide a comfortable structure that allowed them to function normally despite the personal undercurrents that had emerged between them. It was both reassuring and slightly frustrating—part of him wanted to acknowledge what had changed, to find some way of integrating their personal revelation with their professional partnership.

**Chapter 3**

Back at the police station, Spencer and Marcus settled into the systematic work of tracking down Martin Fletcher's current whereabouts. Can you tell us about the procedures for handling client data at Crossover Financial?"

Fletcher seemed to relax slightly, apparently reassured that the questions weren't directly accusatory. "Standard procedures, really. "Did you ever have occasion to visit clients at their homes?" Marcus asked. "As part of your assessment work?"

"Sometimes," Fletcher admitted. "Property assessments, damage evaluations, that kind of thing. It was part of the job to understand the context of what we were insuring."

This was exactly the kind of access that would have allowed Fletcher to observe client routines, to note when houses were typically empty and what kinds of valuables might be present. Spencer felt the investigation beginning to coalesce around their suspect, though they still needed more concrete evidence to justify an arrest.

"Do you keep records of your client visits?" Spencer continued. "Appointment books, mileage logs, that sort of thing?"

Fletcher's eyes flicked nervously toward a pile of papers on his table. "Some records, yes. Though I'm not sure how detailed they are. Why do you ask?"

Before Spencer could respond, his attention was caught by something visible through Fletcher's front window. A dark blue hatchback was parked directly outside the building, matching Mrs. Morrison's description of the car she'd seen Fletcher loading with electronic equipment. Spencer gestured subtly to Marcus, who followed his gaze and nodded slightly in acknowledgment.

"That's a nice car," Marcus commented, moving toward the window as if to get a better view. "Yours?"

"Yes," Fletcher replied, but his voice had taken on a strained quality that hadn't been present earlier in their conversation. "Nothing fancy, but it gets me around."

Spencer felt the pieces of their investigation clicking into place with the satisfying precision of a well-constructed puzzle. Fletcher had motive—resentment toward his former employer and financial desperation. He had means—detailed knowledge of client routines and homes, plus transportation to carry out burglaries and transport stolen goods. And now they had opportunity—evidence of expensive items in his possession that needed explanation and a vehicle matching witness descriptions.

Spencer saw him glance toward the door, then toward the boxes of equipment stacked against the wall, his mind clearly racing through possibilities for escape or concealment.

"I think," Fletcher said slowly, "I should probably call a solicitor."

**Chapter 5**

They needed more concrete evidence to break through his carefully prepared responses.

"That's an interesting business model," Marcus said conversationally, leaning back in his chair with the casual posture that often lured suspects into overconfidence. "How do you find your suppliers? People looking to sell electronics quickly for cash?"
